text: (bright music)
- [Wei-Han] Hello, my name's Wei-Han
and I am a technical business developer

at AWS Marketplace
International Expansion team.

In this video, I will be
walking you through new features
available today on AWS Marketplace,
local currency offers and disbursement.

You will learn how you
can accept private offers

in local currencies as
an AWS Marketplace buyer.
Previously, AWS Marketplace sellers
can only sell in US dollars.

Buyers can choose to pay
invoices in local currencies.

However, the invoicing
amounts from US dollar

to local currencies is
only visible to the buyer
at the time of invoice receipt.
For deals with future invoicing dates,
and especially multi-year transactions,
buyers will then face
a foreign exchange for variability risk.
To address these points of friction,

we are rolling out changes in
2024 that I'll dive into next.

Let's go over the scope
of what's being launched
in the remainder of 2024.

In 2024, we will be enabling
AWS Marketplace sellers

to create offers in four
additional non-US dollar currencies

and receive disbursements
in local bank accounts.
More specifically with this launch,

sellers will be able to create
private offers using euro,

British pounds, Japanese yen,
and the Australian dollar.

Sellers will also be able
to receive disbursements
in that same currency.

Next, sellers can now
receive disbursements

in local bank accounts
in eligible jurisdictions

like EU, UK, Australia or
Japan to receive disbursements.

And finally, buyers
will be able to procure
software and services from AWS Marketplace

with all the current foreign
exchange variability risk
since the buyers can now be invoiced

directly in the same currency
as used in a private offer
by the seller.

Now, let's deep dive into
some considerations for buyers

to transact private offers
in local currencies.

You can now negotiate private
offers with contract pricing

directly in local
currencies with your seller.
The private offer needs to be using

contract pricing products
such as SaaS contract
or professional services.

If you receive a private
offer in a local currency,
then when you accept the private offer,
you will be invoiced based on the currency
in a private offer

regardless of your
preferred currency setting.
Finally, on the tax handling,
similar to the experience today,

you will continue to receive
tax invoices when applicable.
If you are an AWS Marketplace seller

and want to learn more about
how to add local bank accounts

and create private offers
in local currencies,
please watch our other two videos

that will guide you
through both processes.

Now I will show you how you
can accept private offers
in local currencies inside AWS console.
Before you accept the private offer,

verify which AWS account you
want to use for the transaction

and accounts payment method,
as well as a payment currency

to ensure that you can pay the
invoices in local currencies.
Log into your AWS account,
navigate to Billing and Cost Management.
On the left hand side,

if you scroll all the way down
under Payment Preferences,
you can verify your payment method,
as well as the payment currency.

If you would like to
verify your tax setting,

then scroll all the way
down on the left-hand side
and navigate to tax settings.

Here, you will see all the
tax registrations available
under your account.

Now to accept private
offers in local currencies,

you can ask a seller to send
you the private offer URL

or navigate to AWS Marketplace
directly inside the console.

On the left-hand side under
the Private offers tab,

you will see all available
private offers to be accepted.
Click on the offer URL.
Review the offer details,
in particular the contract currency,

as well as the invoice
schedule for this transaction.

In this example, when I
accept this private offer,

I will be charged
directly in British pounds

for the entire duration
of the subscription.
Once you confirm the payment schedule,

then you are good to
accept this private offer.
(bright music)
